title: Where Are You on the AI Developer Journey?

meta.description: Discover your stage in AI adoption as a developer through an interactive assessment

hero.title: Where Are You on the AI Developer Journey?
hero.subtitle: Discover your stage in AI adoption through an interactive assessment inspired by interview with 22 AI-powered developers

questions.question: How do you typically use AI tools in your development work?

options.text: I rarely use them, or only for very basic tasks
Mainly for code completion and simple debugging
For multi-step tasks and iterative problem solving
As strategic partners for complex feature development

questions.question: What's your tolerance for AI-generated errors?

options.text: Very low - I expect it to work perfectly the first time
I'm learning to iterate but get frustrated with multiple attempts
I embrace iterative prompting and refinement
I strategically use errors as learning opportunities for better delegation

questions.question: How do you approach prompting AI tools?

options.text: Simple, one-line requests
I copy-paste from browser-based LLMs when needed
I prompt for plans first and build context engineering intuition
I create elaborate, multi-agent workflows with detailed instructions

questions.question: What types of tasks do you delegate to AI?

options.text: Only very basic code snippets and simple questions
Debugging issues and generating boilerplate code
Multi-file changes and moderately complex features
Large-scale refactoring and complete feature development

questions.question: How do you verify AI-generated code?

options.text: I expect it to work without much verification
Basic testing and reviewing for obvious errors
Thorough review and testing with understanding of AI limitations
Systematic validation with extensive testing and architectural review

questions.question: What's your experience with different AI models and tools?

options.text: I stick to one basic tool and rarely explore alternatives
I experiment with different tools but inconsistently
I strategically switch between tools and understand their strengths
I orchestrate multiple models and tools for optimal outcomes

questions.question: How do you share AI insights with your team?

options.text: I rarely discuss AI tools with colleagues
Occasional mentions when something works well
Active participation in discussions and demos of effective prompts
Leading workshops and establishing team best practices

questions.question: What's your view on AI writing 90% of code in the future?

options.text: Skeptical - I don't see how that could work effectively
Curious but concerned about quality and reliability
Optimistic - I can see how delegation and verification could work
Confident - I'm already moving towards that model successfully

questions.question: How has AI changed your role as a developer?

options.text: It hasn't significantly changed what I do
I'm faster at certain tasks but my role is mostly the same
I'm becoming more of a collaborator and context engineer
I've shifted to delegation, verification, and architectural thinking

questions.question: What motivates your AI tool usage?

options.text: Curiosity, but I'm not convinced of the long-term value
Time savings and efficiency improvements
Expanding what I can accomplish and build
Preparing for fundamental changes in software development

share.text:
I'm at Stage {stage}: {title} on my AI Developer Journey!

Discover your AI development stage at:

stage1.title: AI Skeptic
stage1.summary: Dabbling with AI in small tasks and questions. Developers are primarily working with code completions and have low tolerance for iteration and errors.
stage1.description: You're in the early exploration phase, dabbling with AI in small tasks and questions. You primarily work with code completions and have low tolerance for iteration and errors.
characteristics: Using AI for simple code completion
nextSteps: Target Specific, Annoying Tasks: Use AI for tasks you hate, like writing a README.md, generating a basic Dockerfile, or converting JSON to a TypeScript interface.
Practice 'Iterative Correction': When an answer is wrong, make one small, specific correction, like '...can you do it using a pure function?' or '...try again using the requests library.'
Use It as a Smart Rubber Duck: Paste your broken code and error message, then ask, 'What is the most likely cause of this error? Explain it step-by-step.'
tools: GitHub Copilot (in your IDE): Focus on accepting or cycling through its single-line and block-level completions.
ChatGPT / Claude (Free versions): Use the web interface for isolated questions that don't require your project's context.
Phind.com: Use for questions where you want to verify the answer with cited sources.

stage2.title: AI Explorer
stage2.summary: Using AI for debugging, boilerplate and snippets. With practice, they embrace iterative prompting and realize when to start over instead of pushing forward.
stage2.description: You're using AI for debugging, boilerplate and snippets, starting to understand AI's limitations. You work with completions and chat, copy-paste from browser-based LLMs.
characteristics: Using AI for debugging and boilerplate
Learning to iterate but still get frustrated
nextSteps: Master the 'Context Sandwich': Structure prompts with: 1. Persona, 2. Context (paste your code), 3. Task, and 4. Constraints ('Do not use external libraries').
Plan Before You Code: For any non-trivial task, first ask the AI to create a plan, e.g., 'Outline the high-level steps to add Google OAuth login.'
Use AI-Native IDE Features: Highlight code and use the 'inline chat' or 'edit with AI' feature to refactor it or add comments directly within your editor.
tools: AI-Integrated IDE (Cursor, VS Code w/ Copilot Chat): This is the key tool for this stage, keeping the AI conversation next to your code.
ChatGPT Plus / Claude Pro: The paid tiers provide faster responses, better models, and the ability to upload files for context.
Perplexity.ai: Excellent for research-oriented questions where you need to trace the source of the AI's claims.

stage3.title: AI Collaborator
stage3.summary: Actively co-creating with AI, using AI-enabled IDEs for multi-step tasks and adopting habits like prompting for a plan first and strategically switching between tools.
stage3.description: You're actively co-creating with AI and building context engineering intuition. You use AI-enabled IDEs for multi-step tasks and have adopted effective prompting strategies.
characteristics: Using AI for multi-step tasks and multi-file changes
Switching strategically between tools and models
Sharing effective prompts with team members
nextSteps: Chain Your Prompts: Treat a feature as a sequence of prompts (e.g., 1. Propose a plan, 2. Implement the component, 3. Write the tests).
Build a Personal Prompt Library: Create a `my_prompts.md` file to save your most effective prompts, categorized by task (Refactoring, Debugging, etc.).
Delegate Full-File Creation: Trust the AI to generate an entire file from a detailed prompt specifying its name, class, methods, and logic.
tools: Your own `prompts.md` file: Your most important tool, a personal, battle-tested playbook.
A Second LLM: Use a different model (e.g., Claude if you main OpenAI) when you get stuck to get a different perspective.
Team Slack/Discord Channel: Create a dedicated channel (e.g., `#ai-prompts`) to share successful workflows with your team.

stage4.title: AI Strategist
stage4.summary: Treating AI as a powerful partner for complex tasks, building elaborate multi-agent workflows with increasing autonomy and parallelism.
stage4.description: You treat AI as a powerful partner for feature development, complex tasks, and large-scale refactoring. You've built elaborate, multi-agent workflows with high autonomy.
characteristics: Leading team adoption and best practices
nextSteps: Automate Verification: Mandate that significant AI-generated code must be accompanied by AI-generated tests. Review the tests first.
Systematize Mentoring: Host a monthly 30-minute 'AI Workflow' session to live-demo how you solved a recent problem and share your prompt library.
Build Small, Custom Agents: Write simple scripts (Python/Node.js) using an LLM's API to automate specific, repetitive company tasks.
tools: Simple API Scripts (Python/Node.js): Use libraries like `openai` or `anthropic` to create repeatable, version-controlled AI workflows.
Orchestration Frameworks (e.g., LangChain, LlamaIndex): Begin experimenting with these to chain multiple LLM calls and connect to other data sources.
Internal Documentation (Confluence/Notion): Create a living document of 'AI Best Practices' for your team.

about.title: About This Assessment
about.description: This interactive assessment is inspired by Thomas Dohmke's interview with 22 developers who heavily use AI tools. The four stages represent a natural progression from skepticism to strategic AI partnership, reimagined as an engaging self-assessment tool.
